elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with 4-pyr-poly-2-ene (ppene) in the presence of benzene-1,2-dicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2BDC), benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2BDC), benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2BDC), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (1,3,5-H3BTC), or 4,4′-oxidibenzoic acid (4,4′-H2OBA) afforded five Cd­(II) coordination polymers [Cd­(ppene)­(1,2-BDC)] n (1), [Cd­(ppene)­(1,3-BDC)] n (2), [{Cd­(ppene)­(1,4-BDC)}­·MeCN] n (3) (Liu et al. Inorg. Chem. Commun. 2015, 58, 1−4 ), [{Cd­(ppene)­(1,3,5-HBTC)}­·0.5­(ppene)] n (4), and [Cd­(ppene)­(4,4′-OBA)] n (5), respectively. Upon UV light irradiation, 1, 3, and 4 can undergo a double [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction to yield their corresponding photoproducts including [Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,2-BDC)2] n (1a, 4-tp-3-lad = 2,3,5,6-tetra­(pyridin-4-yl)­bicyclo[2.2.0]­hexane), [{Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,4-BDC)2}­·2MeCN] n (3a), and [{Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,3,5-HBTC)2}­·(ppene)] n (4a) in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal manner. Compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, 1a, 3a, and 4a have been structurally characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1, 1a, 4 and 4a consist of two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) networks, in which one-dimensional (1D) [Cd2(1,2-BDC)2] n or [Cd2(1,3,5-HBTC)2] n chains are linked by ppene or 4-tp-3-lad bridges. 2 has a three-dimensional (3D) 3-fold interpenetrated framework formed from bridging 1D [Cd2(1,3-BDC)2] n double chains by ppene ligands. Compounds 3a and 5 contain 3D frameworks assembled by linking 2D [Cd2(1,4-BDC)2] n or [Cd2(4,4′-OBA)2] n networks by 4-tp-3-lad or ppene bridges. In the three photoreactions, each ppene ligand had its two conjugated CC bonds parallel to those of the neighboring ppene. The resulting ppene pair was transformed into the only product, 4-tp-3-lad, through a unique double [2 + 2] cycloaddition. Photoluminescence properties of these compounds in water were also investigated. Compound 3a as a representative example was proven to be an efficient probe for dual detections of nitroaromatics and Hg2+ in aqueous solutions.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with 4-pyr-poly-2-ene (ppene) and different carboxylic acids produced a set of Cd­(II) coordination polymers with different topological structures. Some of these compounds could undertake a double [2 + 2] photodimerization in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal manner, and the resulting photoproducts exhibited high selectivity and sensitivity for the dual-purpose luminescent detection of nitroaromatics and Hg2+ in water.

elements.content: In the past few decades, solid-state structural transformations of metal coordination complexes have drawn much attention because of their potential applications in adsorption, catalysis, magnetism, molecular switch, and photochemical reactivity. Several approaches to these transformations including uptake/release/exchange of guest molecules, oxidation of metal centers, exchange of metal centers or ligands, dimensionality change, and others have been developed. An additional approach, the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition of olefinic bonds in metal coordination complexes, has been proved to be a fascinating methodology, given its facile reactivity, regio-selectivity, and high yield. The [2 + 2] photodimerizations that have occurred in some coordination compounds have been reported to change or improve their physical or chemical properties. For example, one dimeric complex [Ag2(4-stilbz)4]­[CF3SO3]2 (4-stilbz = 4-styrylpyridine) underwent a [2 + 2] photodimerization to generate a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer with over 40% higher conductivity. Moreover, the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction is an efficient tool to increase the coordination dentate numbers of organic ligands, forming higher-dimensional coordination polymers in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) manner. To date, many ligands containing a single CC double bond such as 4-styrylpyridine and 1,2-bis­(4′-pyridyl)­ethylene have been extensively investigated in various photochemical [2 + 2] reactions. However, the photodimerizations of organic conjugated dialkene dipyridyl molecules in coordination complexes have been less explored. Among these conjugated dialkene dipyridyl ligands, 4-pyr-poly-2-ene (ppene) is a good candidate, which can have two different CC arrangements, denoted as type I and type II in . Upon UV light irradiation, the type I arrangement may undergo a [2 + 2] cycloaddition of one CC bond pair to form 4,4′-(2,4-bis­(2-(pyridin-4-yl)­vinyl)­cyclobutane-1,3-diyl)­dipyridine (bpbpvcb) (product a), while the type II may experience the other [2 + 2] cycloaddition of one CC bond pair, a double [2 + 2] cycloaddition of double CC bond pairs, or a [4 + 4] cycloaddition, forming the corresponding photoproducts including 4,4′-(3,4-bis­(2-(pyridin-4-yl)­vinyl)­cyclobutane-1,2-diyl)­dipyridine (product b), 2,3,5,6-tetra­(pyridin-4-yl)­bicyclo[2.2.0]­hexane) (4-tp-3-lad, product c), and 3,4,7,8-tetra­(pyridin-4-yl)­cycloocta-1,5-diene (product d) (). Therefore, controlling the region-selective photodimerization of the CC bonds of this conjugated dialkene ligand, ppene, in coordination compounds should be of interest but remains a great challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past few decades, solid-state structural transformations of metal coordination complexes have drawn much attention because of their potential applications in adsorption, catalysis, magnetism, molecular switch, and photochemical reactivity. Several approaches to these transformations including uptake/release/exchange of guest molecules, oxidation of metal centers, exchange of metal centers or ligands, dimensionality change, and others have been developed. An additional approach, the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition of olefinic bonds in metal coordination complexes, has been proved to be a fascinating methodology, given its facile reactivity, regio-selectivity, and high yield. The [2 + 2] photodimerizations that have occurred in some coordination compounds have been reported to change or improve their physical or chemical properties. For example, one dimeric complex [Ag2(4-stilbz)4][CF3SO3]2 (4-stilbz = 4-styrylpyridine) underwent a [2 + 2] photodimerization to generate a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer with over 40% higher conductivity. Moreover, the photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction is an efficient tool to increase the coordination dentate numbers of organic ligands, forming higher-dimensional coordination polymers in a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) manner. To date, many ligands containing a single CC double bond such as 4-styrylpyridine and 1,2-bis(4'-pyridyl)ethylene have been extensively investigated in various photochemical [2 + 2] reactions. However, the photodimerizations of organic conjugated dialkene dipyridyl molecules in coordination complexes have been less explored. Among these conjugated dialkene dipyridyl ligands, 4-pyr-poly-2-ene (ppene) is a good candidate, which can have two different CC arrangements, denoted as type I and type II in . Upon UV light irradiation, the type I arrangement may undergo a [2 + 2] cycloaddition of one CC bond pair to form 4,4'-(2,4-bis(2-(pyridin-4-yl)vinyl)cyclobutane-1,3-diyl)dipyridine (bpbpvcb) (product a), while the type II may experience the other [2 + 2] cycloaddition of one CC bond pair, a double [2 + 2] cycloaddition of double CC bond pairs, or a [4 + 4] cycloaddition, forming the corresponding photoproducts including 4,4'-(3,4-bis(2-(pyridin-4-yl)vinyl)cyclobutane-1,2-diyl)dipyridine (product b), 2,3,5,6-tetra(pyridin-4-yl)bicyclo[2.2.0]hexane) (4-tp-3-lad, product c), and 3,4,7,8-tetra(pyridin-4-yl)cycloocta-1,5-diene (product d) (). Therefore, controlling the region-selective photodimerization of the CC bonds of this conjugated dialkene ligand, ppene, in coordination compounds should be of interest but remains a great challenge.

elements.content: On the other hand, efficient and selective detection of explosive nitroaromatics and toxic mercuric (Hg2+) ion in water systems have aroused increasing attention due to their importance in homeland security, environmental safety, and their high toxicity to human beings. Various detection methods have been established, among which the fluorescence-based technique has been demonstrated to be a promising approach owing to its advantages in operability, rapid response, simplicity, real-time, and high selectivity. A large number of functional organic molecules, polymers, and nanoscale materials have been designed and prepared for this purpose. Since coordination polymers (CPs)-based materials were employed to detect trace amounts of 2,4-dinitrotoluene and 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane in the vapor phase, a wide range of fluorescent CPs-based sensors have been designed and synthesized for probing nitroaromatics or Hg2+ ion. However, the CPs-based materials that can be used to perform the dual fluorescent detection of nitroaromatics and Hg2+ ion are quite limited. Recently, we have been interested in the synthesis and photochemical reactions of CPs with organic alkene ligands and found some of them exhibited good performance in sensing harmful compounds with high selectivity and sensitivity. For our continuous efforts on the [2 + 2] photodimerization of alkenes in the crystalline state and the luminescent sensing properties of coordination polymers, we selected ppene to react solvothermally with Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O in the presence of benzene-1,2-dicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2BDC), benzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2BDC), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2BDC), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (1,3,5-H3BTC), and 4,4′-oxidibenzoic acid (4,4′-H2OBA) (). Five coordination polymers [Cd­(ppene)­(1,2-BDC)] n (1), [Cd­(ppene)­(1,3-BDC)] n (2), [{Cd­(ppene)­(1,4-BDC)}­·MeCN] n (3), [{Cd­(ppene)­(1,3,5-HBTC)}­·0.5­(ppene)] n (4), and [Cd­(ppene)­(4,4′-OBA)] n (5) were isolated. Notably, last year, Liu et al. also reported the synthesis and structure and solid state luminescent properties of 3, but they did not examine its photodimerization and luminescent sensing properties. In this work, we employed these five compounds to systematically study the effects of dicarboxylate ligands on the CC arrangements of ppene pairs, the topological structures, the photodimerizations, and luminescent probing properties in water. Compounds 1, 3, and 4 undertook an SCSC photochemical cycloaddition to yield their corresponding photoproducts [Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,2-BDC)2] n (1a), [{Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,4-BDC)2}­·2MeCN] n (3a), and [{Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,3,5-HBTC)2}­·(ppene)] n (4a), respectively. In these three photoreactions, each pair of ppene ligands followed the type II alignment and was solely transformed into the product c (4-tp-3-lad) (). The representative sample 3a could work as a dual-targeted luminescent probe for detecting nitroaromatics such as 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 4-nitrophenol (NP), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), or nitrobenzene (NB) and Hg2+ in water. Compound 3a exhibited a higher sensitivity with a lower detection limit of 0.12 ppm of 2,4-DNP in aqueous solutions, inferred from fluorescence quenching studies. Herein we describe their synthesis, structural characterization, double [2 + 2] photocycloaddition, and luminescence sensing properties.

elements.content: Compound 3 and ppene were prepared according to the literature methods. Other chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Varian Scamiter-1000 spectrometer (4000–400 cm–1). Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. The photoluminescent spectra were obtained on a HORIBA QM-40 spectrofluorometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a PANalyticalX’Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Compound 3 and ppene were prepared according to the literature methods. Other chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Varian Scamiter-1000 spectrometer (4000-400 cm-1). Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. The photoluminescent spectra were obtained on a HORIBA QM-40 spectrofluorometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a PANalyticalX'Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60).

elements.content: To a Pyrex glass tube (15 cm in length, 7 mm in inner diameter) was loaded Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,2-H2BDC (17 mg, 0.1 mmol), ppene (20 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2 mL of H2O, and 1 mL of MeCN. The tube was sealed and heated in an oven to 150 °C for 1 day and cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C per 60 min to give pale yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN and Et2O, and dried in vacuo. Yield: 17 mg (35% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C22H16CdN2O4: C, 54.51; H, 3.33; N, 5.78%; found: C, 54.65; H, 3.37; N, 5.74%. IR (KBr disc): 3442 (m), 3031 (w), 1631 (s), 1605 (s), 1580 (s), 1548 (s), 1504 (w), 1429 (w), 1393 (s), 1328 (s), 1222 (w), 1135 (w), 1072 (w), 1018 (m), 989 (m), 857 (m), 821 (m), 790 (m), 767 (m), 726 (m), 692 (m), 649 (m), 508 (m), 431­(m) cm–1.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1, 2, 4, 5, 1a, 3a, and 4a suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. Their crystal data were collected on an Agilent Xcalibur (1, 2, 4, 5) or a Bruker D8-Quest (1a, 3a, 4a) diffractometer equipped with Mo Kα radiation (graphite monochromated, λ = 0.71073 Å). CrysAlisPro (Agilent Technologies, CrysAlis171. NET, Ver. 1.71.36.28) and SAINT (Bruker) were employed to process the data of 1, 2, 4, 5, 1a, 3a, and 4a. An absorption correction (multiscan) was applied for all these compounds. The crystal structures of 1, 2, 4, 5, 1a, 3a, and 4a were solved by direct methods. Except of MeCN solvent molecules in 3a and the disordered C6–C9 and C6A–C9A atoms in 4a, all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by full-matrix least-square method. For 4a, C6–C9 atoms are disordered into two sites with the occupancy factors of C6–C9/C6A–C9A = 0.62/0.38. SIMU, DELU and ISOR commands were used for C6–C9/C6A–C9A atoms. Hydrogen atoms of C6A-C9A in 4a were not located. All other hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. A summary of key crystallographic data for 1, 2, 4, 5, 1a, 3a, and 4a were given in . Their selected bond lengths and angles were listed in Table S1.

Solvothermal reactions of Cd­(NO3)2 with 1 equiv of ppene and 1 equiv of 1,2-H2BDC in H2O/MeCN (v/v = 2/1) at 150 °C produced one two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer 1 in 35% yield. When the same reaction was carried out at lower temperatures (e.g., 120 °C) or higher temperatures (e.g., 170 °C), 1 could be obtained in lower yields (ca. 12%). Compound 1 was the only product regardless of the molar ratios of three components. Similar reactions of Cd­(NO3)2 with ppene in the presence of 1,3-H2BDC, 1,4-H2BDC, 1,3,5-H3BTC, or 4,4′-H2OBA in a mixed H2O and MeCN solvent system produced three three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers 2 (66% yield) and 5 (22% yield), and one 2D coordination polymer 4 (33% yield). Complexes 1, 2, 4, and 5 are air and moisture stable and insoluble in common organic solvents such as CHCl3, MeOH, MeCN, DMF, and DMSO. The elemental analyses are also consistent with their chemical formula. In the IR spectra of 1, 2, 4, and 5, the bands at 1450–1600 cm–1 and 1300–1400 cm–1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the coordinated carboxyl groups. The band at 1159 cm–1 represents the existence of the ether bond in 5. The PXRD patterns of 1, 2, 4, and 5 match quite well with those of the corresponding ones simulated from their single-crystal X-ray data, suggesting the phase purity of these compounds (Figure S1). The identities of 1, 2, 4, and 5 are further established by the single crystal X-ray analysis.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis of 1, 2, 4, and 5 

Solvothermal reactions of Cd(NO3)2 with 1 equiv of ppene and 1 equiv of 1,2-H2BDC in H2O/MeCN (v/v = 2/1) at 150 °C produced one two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer 1 in 35% yield. When the same reaction was carried out at lower temperatures (e.g., 120 °C) or higher temperatures (e.g., 170 °C), 1 could be obtained in lower yields (ca. 12%). Compound 1 was the only product regardless of the molar ratios of three components. Similar reactions of Cd(NO3)2 with ppene in the presence of 1,3-H2BDC, 1,4-H2BDC, 1,3,5-H3BTC, or 4,4'-H2OBA in a mixed H2O and MeCN solvent system produced three three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers 2 (66% yield) and 5 (22% yield), and one 2D coordination polymer 4 (33% yield). Complexes 1, 2, 4, and 5 are air and moisture stable and insoluble in common organic solvents such as CHCl3, MeOH, MeCN, DMF, and DMSO. The elemental analyses are also consistent with their chemical formula. In the IR spectra of 1, 2, 4, and 5, the bands at 1450-1600 cm-1 and 1300-1400 cm-1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the coordinated carboxyl groups. The band at 1159 cm-1 represents the existence of the ether bond in 5. The PXRD patterns of 1, 2, 4, and 5 match quite well with those of the corresponding ones simulated from their single-crystal X-ray data, suggesting the phase purity of these compounds (Figure S1). The identities of 1, 2, 4, and 5 are further established by the single crystal X-ray analysis.

elements.content: As discussed later in this article, in the structures of 1 and 3, each of the two conjugated double bonds in one ppene ligand is closely aligned in a parallel arrangement with another ppene, forming the type II arrangement with a separation of 3.78 and 3.80 Å for 1 and 3.68 and 3.69 Å for 3. These contacts fall within the range of contacts established by Schmidt as being necessary for photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions to proceed. To explore their photoreactivity, single crystals and crystalline powder samples of 1 and 3 were thus exposed to UV light (365 nm) irradiation (400 W high-pressure Hg-lamp) for a period of approximately 12 h. The morphologies and transparent appearance were retained. The single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that each pair of the ppene molecules in 1 or 3 underwent a double [2 + 2] cycloaddition to yield the product c (), 4-tp-3-lad, via a SCSC style, thereby producing [Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,2-BDC)2] n (1a) and [{Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,4-BDC)2}­·2MeCN] n (3a), respectively. Their space groups were maintained and their structures were also retained during such a structural transformation. Each pyridyl group of 4-tp-3-lad is still coordinated to the same Cd­(II) center. After the solid samples of 1a or 3a were digested by NaOH and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium salt followed by a standard workup, the photoproduct 4-tp-3-lad was isolated and further confirmed by 1H NMR spectrum. The signals of olefinic protons of ppene at δ 7.4 and 6.8 ppm disappeared. The appearance of the signals at δ 3.5 and 4.3 ppm showed the formation of three fused cyclobutane rings. Relative to those of ppene, the resonances of the protons of pyridyl ring of 4-tp-3-lad had a remarkable upfield shift from δ 8.5 to 8.3 ppm and from δ 7.5 ppm to 7.0 ppm (Figures S2 and S3). These changes of the proton signals suggested that the ppene ligands underwent a double [2 + 2] cycloaddition into 4-tp-3-lad ligand in a quantitative yield. For 4, the double bonds in the coordinated ppene ligands separated by 3.87 and 3.89 Å are aligned for a photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition. However, the distance between two uncoordinated ppene lattice molecules is 10.28 Å, which exceeds Schmidt’s distance limit for a photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition. After the exposure of single crystals of 4 to UV irradiation for 12 h, about 38% of the coordinated ppene ligands were converted into 4-tp-3-lad, but the uncoordinated ppene ligands remained intact according to the X-ray diffraction analysis. After further UV irradiation for about 48 h, each single crystal of 4 got cracked. Following a similar method mentioned above, liquid chromatography (LC) analysis of the organic species isolated from the irradiated samples indicated that the 4-tp-3-lad/ppene molar ratio was about 2:1. The results suggested that the cycloaddition reaction of the coordinated ppene ligand in 4 might be complete. For 2 or 5, the C···C distances (4.5 and 8.9 Å) of the nearest ppene pair are greater than 4.2 Å, excluding any possible photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reactions. We attempted to extend UV light irradiation over crystals of 2 or 5 for more than 2 days. Both compounds still remained inert for any photochemical reaction according to their single-crystal X-ray analysis, LC and 1H NMR spectra. Thus, in our case, each ppene pair in the structures of 1, 3, or 4 has type II alignment, and the UV irradiation over 1, 3, or 4 exclusively led to the formation of the [3]-ladderane-like molecule, 4-tp-3-lad. This highly selective double [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction is different from the [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction (type I in ) found in [Zn4(OH)2(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)2­(5-NO2-1,3-HBDC)2(ppene)2] n (5-NO2-1,3-HBDC = 5-nitrobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid), which was converted into [Zn4(OH)2­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)2­(5-NO2-1,3-HBDC)2­(bpbpvcb)] n (bpbpvcb = product a in ) upon UV irradiation. Such a difference is probably due to their different coordination polymer structures that decide the CC arrangement styles of each ppene pair, which subsequently decide the final photoproducts.

elements.content: Compound 1 or 1a crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and each asymmetric unit contains one [Cd­(ppene)­(1,2-BDC)] unit (1) or half of one [Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,2-BDC)2] unit (1a). In 1 or 1a, each 1,2-BDC ligand takes a μ3-κ2O,O′:κ2O′,O″:κ1O″ mode to bind at three Cd centers. Each Cd in 1 or 1a is seven-coordinated by five O atoms from three 1,2-BDC ligands and two N atoms from two ppene ligands or one 4-tp-3-lad ligand (a). Compound 1 or 1a has a 2D network in which 1D [Cd2(1,2-BDC)2] n chains (b) are interconnected by ppene (1) or 4-tp-3-lad (1a) bridges (c,d). In 1, two pairs of the CC bonds are parallel, and the distances between them are 3.78 and 3.80 Å, respectively. The mean Cd–N and Cd–O bond lengths (2.324(4) Å vs 2.416(3) Å) are comparable to those of the corresponding ones in [Cd­(fdc)­(bipy)1.5] (2.368(2) Å vs 2.432(3) Å; fdc = 2,5-furandicarboxylate, biby = 4,4′-bipyridine). In 1a, the average Cd–N and Cd–O bond lengths (2.313(6) Å vs 2.410(6) Å) are close to those of the corresponding ones in 1. The Cd···Cd distance of 3.69 Å in 1a is slightly longer than that in 1 (3.64 Å).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and its asymmetric unit consists of one [Cd­(ppene)­(1,3-BDC)] unit. In 2, each Cd­(II) is octahedrally coordinated by four O atoms from three 1,3-BDC ligands and two N atoms from two ppene ligands (a). Two carboxylate groups of each 1,3-BDC ligand in 2 bind to three Cd­(II) atoms through a chelating bidentate fashion and a bridging μ–κ1O:κ1O′ coordination mode. Two Cd centers are bridged by a pair of 1,3-BDC ligands to form a dimeric [Cd2(1,3-BDC)2] fragment. Such a unit is connected by 1,3-BDC ligands to its equivalent ones, forming a 1D [Cd2(1,3-BDC)2] n double chain (b). These 1D chains are interlinked by ppene ligands to yield a 3D framework (c). Three such nets are further interpenetrated to afford a 3-fold interpenetrated 3D structure (d). Topologically, 2 can be regarded as a 3D net with a pcu topology, if the [Cd2(1,3-BDC)2] fragment is treated as an octahedral 6-connecting node. The average Cd–N bond length (2.364(2) Å) is similar to that of the corresponding one in 1, while the mean Cd–O bond length (2.338(2) Å) is shorter than the one in 1.

elements.content: Compound 3a crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and each asymmetric unit contains half of a [Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,4-BDC)2] unit and one MeCN molecule. In 3a, each 1,4-BDC ligand binds to one or two Cd­(II) centers through a chelating bidentate mode or a bridging μ–κ1O:κ1O′ coordination fashion, respectively. Each Cd is octahedrally coordinated by four O atoms from three 1,4-BDC ligands and two N atoms from two 4-tp-3-lad ligands (a). Each 2D [Cd2(1,4-BDC)2] n layer is linked to its neighboring ones by 4-tp-3-lad bridges to afford one 3D net (b). Two 3D nets are further interpenetrated into each other to form a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework that is similar to that of its parent compound 3. The average Cd–N bond length (2.323(5) Å) and Cd–O bond lengths (2.362(6) Å) in 3a are slightly longer than those of the corresponding ones in 3 (2.3165(4) Å; 2.3478(3) Å), which are caused by the strain of the cyclobutane rings formed in 3a.

elements.content: Compound 4 or 4a crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and each asymmetric unit consists of one [Cd­(ppene)­(1,3,5-HBTC)] unit and one ppene lattice molecule (4) or half of a [Cd2(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,3,5-HBTC)2] unit and one ppene lattice molecule (4a). Each Cd center is octahedrally coordinated by four O atoms from three 1,3,5-HBTC ligands and two N atoms from two ppene (4) or 4-tp-3-lad ligands (4a) (a). Two of the three carboxylate groups of 1,3,5-HBTC ligand in 4 bind to two Cd­(II) centers through a chelating bidentate fashion and a bridging μ–κ1O:κ1O′ coordination mode. The third COOH group retains intact. The mean Cd–N and Cd–O bond lengths in 4 (2.307(2) Å vs 2.344(2) Å) are comparable to those of the corresponding ones in 3. In 4 or 4a, there exists a 1D double chain of Cd centers bridged by 1,3,5-HBTC ligands (b). The resulting chains are connected by ppene or 4-tp-3-lad ligands to give a 2D network (c,d). In 4, each of the two conjugated double bonds in one coordinated ppene ligand is closely aligned in a parallel arrangement with a double bond in its neighbor, with a separation of 3.87 or 3.89 Å. The neighboring Cd···Cd contact and Cd–O bond length increases from 3.99 Å/2.344(2) Å (4) to 4.04 Å/2.357(6) Å (4a). The average Cd–N bond length (2.300(5) Å) in 4a is slightly shorter than that in 4. In the 2D structures of 4 and 4a, the free ppene lattice molecules are fixed in-between 2D layers through O–H···N hydrogen-bonding interactions (e).

elements.content: In order to explore the fluorescent sensing properties of these compounds, we investigated the photoluminescent properties of 1–5, 1a, 3a, and 4a, and ppene in water ( and 4S). Upon excitation at 360 nm, the ppene ligand dispersed in water exhibited two emission bands centered at λmax = 390 and 410 nm, respectively. The observed emission origins of ppene probably contributed to the intraligand π–π* and n−π* transitions. When excited at 330 nm (1) or 360 nm (2), compounds 1 and 2 displayed similar absorption mission bands with emission maxima at 394 and 425 nm (1), 405 and 425 nm (2), respectively. Upon excitation at 360 nm (3 and 4), or 370 nm (5), compounds 3–5 presented strong photoluminescence with emission maxima at 404 nm (3), 420 nm (4), and 410 nm (5), respectively. These emission bands of 1–5 can be largely assigned to a ligand-centered emission. Compared with that of ppene, the emission maxima of 1–5 was red-shifted, which may be due to the coordination between ppene and Cd­(II). Besides, the emission peak of 1a (λmax = 394 nm) was similar to that of 1 (Figure S4). However, a red-shift of the emission maxima from 3 to 3a (λmax = 432 nm) and a blue shift of the emission maxima from 4 to 4a (λmax = 413 nm) were observed.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

In order to explore the fluorescent sensing properties of these compounds, we investigated the photoluminescent properties of 1-5, 1a, 3a, and 4a, and ppene in water ( and 4S). Upon excitation at 360 nm, the ppene ligand dispersed in water exhibited two emission bands centered at λmax = 390 and 410 nm, respectively. The observed emission origins of ppene probably contributed to the intraligand π-π* and n-π* transitions. When excited at 330 nm (1) or 360 nm (2), compounds 1 and 2 displayed similar absorption mission bands with emission maxima at 394 and 425 nm (1), 405 and 425 nm (2), respectively. Upon excitation at 360 nm (3 and 4), or 370 nm (5), compounds 3-5 presented strong photoluminescence with emission maxima at 404 nm (3), 420 nm (4), and 410 nm (5), respectively. These emission bands of 1-5 can be largely assigned to a ligand-centered emission. Compared with that of ppene, the emission maxima of 1-5 was red-shifted, which may be due to the coordination between ppene and Cd(II). Besides, the emission peak of 1a (λmax = 394 nm) was similar to that of 1 (Figure S4). However, a red-shift of the emission maxima from 3 to 3a (λmax = 432 nm) and a blue shift of the emission maxima from 4 to 4a (λmax = 413 nm) were observed.

elements.content: As representative examples, a well ground sample of 3 or its photoproduct 3a (1 mg) was suspended in water (2 mL) and sonicated for 30 min. Each sample of 2,4-DNP, NP, 1,3-DNB, or NB (6.5 × 10–4 mmol) was added to the emulsion of 3 or 3a in H2O. As shown in , these nitroaromatics reduced the photoluminescent intensity of the emulsion of 3 or 3a to different degrees. For 3 and 3a, the quenching efficiency of different nitroaromatics followed the order of 2,4-DNP > NP > 1,3-DNB > NB. For 3, the quenching efficiency of these nitroaromatics (QE = (1 – I/I 0) × 100% (I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of nitro derivatives, respectively)) was calculated to be 96%, 88%, 15%, and 7% for 38.3 ppm of 2,4-DNP, NP, 1,3-DNB, and NB, respectively. For 3a, the quenching efficiency of these nitroaromatics was 96% (2,4-DNP), 58% (NP), 6% (1,3-DNB), and 3% (NB), respectively. Among these four nitroaromatics, 2,4-DNP exhibited the highest quenching efficiency of the fluorescence of 3 and 3a. In other words, both 3 and 3a held good sensitivity for probing small amounts of 2,4-DNP in H2O solution, and compound 3a displayed more selective sensing of nitroaromatics than 3.
elements.clean_text:
Nitroaromatics and Hg2+ Photoluminescent Sensing Properties of 3 and 3a 

As representative examples, a well ground sample of 3 or its photoproduct 3a (1 mg) was suspended in water (2 mL) and sonicated for 30 min. Each sample of 2,4-DNP, NP, 1,3-DNB, or NB (6.5 × 10-4 mmol) was added to the emulsion of 3 or 3a in H2O. As shown in , these nitroaromatics reduced the photoluminescent intensity of the emulsion of 3 or 3a to different degrees. For 3 and 3a, the quenching efficiency of different nitroaromatics followed the order of 2,4-DNP > NP > 1,3-DNB > NB. For 3, the quenching efficiency of these nitroaromatics (QE = (1 - I/I 0) × 100% (I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of nitro derivatives, respectively)) was calculated to be 96%, 88%, 15%, and 7% for 38.3 ppm of 2,4-DNP, NP, 1,3-DNB, and NB, respectively. For 3a, the quenching efficiency of these nitroaromatics was 96% (2,4-DNP), 58% (NP), 6% (1,3-DNB), and 3% (NB), respectively. Among these four nitroaromatics, 2,4-DNP exhibited the highest quenching efficiency of the fluorescence of 3 and 3a. In other words, both 3 and 3a held good sensitivity for probing small amounts of 2,4-DNP in H2O solution, and compound 3a displayed more selective sensing of nitroaromatics than 3.

elements.content: In order to gain some insight into the fluorescence quenching process, the suspension of 3 or 3a was titrated with 2,4-DNP in H2O at room temperature (). The Stern–Volmer (SV) plots in water were used to calculate the quenching constant and analyze the quenching efficiency of 2,4-DNP () using the SV equation (I 0/I) = 1 + K sv[2,4-DNP], where I and I 0 are the fluorescence intensities after and before addition of 2,4-DNP, K sv is the quenching constant (M–1), and [2,4-DNP] is the molar concentration of 2,4-DNP. The quenching constant K sv of 3a (5.3 × 104 M–1) is higher than that of 3 (3.3 × 104 M–1). The detection limits of 3 and 3a are calculated to be 0.54 and 0.12 ppm, respectively. These results reveal that 3a is more efficient than 3 in the detection of 2,4-DNP.

elements.content: We also investigated the employment of the fluorescent 3 and 3a for the possible detection of Hg2+ ions in water. As depicted in Figure S4, the emission maximum of 3 in water was slightly red-shifted from 404 to 412 nm along with the increasing amount of Hg2+ (0–0.425 mM), suggesting that 3 could not be used to probe Hg2+ in aqueous solution. However, the emission maximum of 3a in H2O was blue-shifted from 432 to 410 nm along with the increasing amount of Hg2+ (a). Such a blue-shift was gradually accompanied by a decrease of the emission intensity when the concentration of Hg2+ was changed from 0 to 0.125 mM. Upon increasing the Hg2+ concentration up to 0.425 mM, the emission maximum was blue-shifted from 424 to 410 nm, and the emission intensity increased gradually. Moreover, a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.98 for Hg2+) existed between the wavelength and the concentration of Hg2+ in the range of 0–0.425 mM (b). As a result, 3a may be used for probing the lower concentrations of Hg2+ in water.

elements.content: In summary, we demonstrated the construction of two 2D coordination polymers (1 and 4) and two 3D coordination polymers (2 and 5) from solvothermal reactions of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with ppene and 1,2-H2BDC, 1,3-H2BDC, 1,3,5-H3BTC, or 4,4′-H2OBA. In the structures of 1, 2, 4, 5 and the known compound 3, these carboxylates bound at Cd­(II) centers through either a chelating/bridging mode μ3-κ2O,O′:κ2O′,O″:κ1O′ (1) or a chelating bidentate fashion and a bridging μ–κ1O:κ1O′ coordination mode (2, 3, 4, and 5). The presence of these carboxylates also exerted an impact on the CC arrangements of ppene pairs and the structures of the resulting Cd­(II) coordination polymers. In 1, 3, and 4, the CC bonds of each ppene pair displayed the same type II alignment (). Upon UV light irradiation, 1, 3, and 4 experienced a SCSC transformation into their corresponding photoproducts 1a, 3a, and 4a, in which each ppene pair was solely transformed in 4-tp-3-lad (product c in ) through a uncommon double [2 + 2] cycloaddition process. Compounds 3 and 3a as the representative examples served as good dual-purpose luminescent sensors for probing nitroaromatics (2,4-DNP, NP, 1,3-DNB, NB) in water. Relative to 3, compound 3a exhibited higher selectivity and sensitivity with a lower detection limit (0.12 ppm) for 2,4-DNP in aqueous solutions. In addition, 3a could also be employed as a good luminescent probe for sensing Hg2+ in water. It is anticipated that assembly of other metal ions with ppene or other conjugated olefinic dipyridyl ligands could generate more multidimensional coordination polymers with fascinating structures. Some of these compounds may have other photochemical performance to yield other intriguing photoproducts (e.g., products b and d in ). In addition, the results reported in this work may present some insight into the development of new CPs-based materials with potential applications in luminescent probing of nitroaromatics and other toxic metal ions in water.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we demonstrated the construction of two 2D coordination polymers (1 and 4) and two 3D coordination polymers (2 and 5) from solvothermal reactions of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O with ppene and 1,2-H2BDC, 1,3-H2BDC, 1,3,5-H3BTC, or 4,4'-H2OBA. In the structures of 1, 2, 4, 5 and the known compound 3, these carboxylates bound at Cd(II) centers through either a chelating/bridging mode μ3-κ2O,O':κ2O',O":κ1O' (1) or a chelating bidentate fashion and a bridging μ-κ1O:κ1O' coordination mode (2, 3, 4, and 5). The presence of these carboxylates also exerted an impact on the CC arrangements of ppene pairs and the structures of the resulting Cd(II) coordination polymers. In 1, 3, and 4, the CC bonds of each ppene pair displayed the same type II alignment (). Upon UV light irradiation, 1, 3, and 4 experienced a SCSC transformation into their corresponding photoproducts 1a, 3a, and 4a, in which each ppene pair was solely transformed in 4-tp-3-lad (product c in ) through a uncommon double [2 + 2] cycloaddition process. Compounds 3 and 3a as the representative examples served as good dual-purpose luminescent sensors for probing nitroaromatics (2,4-DNP, NP, 1,3-DNB, NB) in water. Relative to 3, compound 3a exhibited higher selectivity and sensitivity with a lower detection limit (0.12 ppm) for 2,4-DNP in aqueous solutions. In addition, 3a could also be employed as a good luminescent probe for sensing Hg2+ in water. It is anticipated that assembly of other metal ions with ppene or other conjugated olefinic dipyridyl ligands could generate more multidimensional coordination polymers with fascinating structures. Some of these compounds may have other photochemical performance to yield other intriguing photoproducts (e.g., products b and d in ). In addition, the results reported in this work may present some insight into the development of new CPs-based materials with potential applications in luminescent probing of nitroaromatics and other toxic metal ions in water.

To a Pyrex glass tube (15 cm in length, 7 mm in inner diameter) was loaded Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,2-H2BDC (17 mg, 0.1 mmol), ppene (20 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2 mL of H2O, and 1 mL of MeCN. The tube was sealed and heated in an oven to 150 °C for 1 day and cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C per 60 min to give pale yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN and Et2O, and dried in vacuo. Yield: 17 mg (35% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C22H16CdN2O4: C, 54.51; H, 3.33; N, 5.78%; found: C, 54.65; H, 3.37; N, 5.74%. IR (KBr disc): 3442 (m), 3031 (w), 1631 (s), 1605 (s), 1580 (s), 1548 (s), 1504 (w), 1429 (w), 1393 (s), 1328 (s), 1222 (w), 1135 (w), 1072 (w), 1018 (m), 989 (m), 857 (m), 821 (m), 790 (m), 767 (m), 726 (m), 692 (m), 649 (m), 508 (m), 431­(m) cm–1.

Synthesis of [Cd­(ppene)­(1,3-BDC)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Pale yellow blocks of 2 were prepared as above starting from Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,3-H2BDC (17 mg, 0.1 mmol), ppene (20 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2O (2 mL), and MeCN (1 mL). Yield: 32 mg (66% yield based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C22H16CdN2O4: C, 54.51; H, 3.33; N, 5.78%; found: C, 54.38; H, 3.47; N, 5.82%. IR (KBr disc): 3455 (s), 3126 (m), 2997 (w), 1603 (s), 1554 (m), 1474 (w), 1426 (w), 1384 (s), 1222 (w), 1141 (m), 1073 (w), 1010 (m), 995 (m), 860 (w), 840 (w), 794 (m), 734 (m), 721 (s), 640 (m), 511 (m), 466 (w), 430 (w) cm–1.

Synthesis of [{Cd­(ppene)­(1,3,5-HBTC)}­·0.5­(ppene)]<sub>n</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Pale yellow blocks of 4 were obtained as above starting from Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,3,5-H3BTC (20 mg, 0.1 mmol), ppene (20 mg, 0.05 mmol), H2O (2 mL), and MeCN (1 mL). Yield: 21 mg (33% yield based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C30H22CdN3O6: C, 56.93; H, 3.50; N, 6.64; found: C, 57.18; H, 3.55; N, 6.40%. IR (KBr disc): 3474 (s), 3127 (m), 2930 (w), 1611 (s), 1560 (s), 1436 (s), 1384 (s), 1143 (m), 1018 (w), 993 (m), 838 (w), 797 (w), 764 (m), 724 (s), 695 (m), 619 (m), 524 (m), 454 (m) cm–1.

Synthesis of [Cd­(ppene)­(4,4′-OBA)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

Pale yellow blocks of 5 were yielded as above starting from Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4,4′-H2OBA (26 mg, 0.1 mmol), ppene (20 mg, 0.05 mmol), 2 mL of H2O, and 1 mL of MeCN. Yield: 13 mg (22% yield based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C28H20CdN2O5: C, 58.30; H, 3.50; N, 4.86; found: C, 57.82; H, 3.88; N, 4.68%. IR (KBr disc): 3474 (m), 3134 (m), 3010 (w), 1602 (s), 1546 (m), 1498 (w), 1397 (s), 1385 (s), 1300 (w), 1255 (m), 1159 (m), 1096 (m), 1011 (m), 995 (m), 880 (m), 858 (m), 841 (m), 794 (m), 779 (m), 656 (m), 646 (m), 641 (m), 624 (m), 511 (m), 466 (w) cm–1.

Synthesis of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,2-BDC)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1a</bold>)

Pale yellow crystals of 1 (0.2 g) were irradiated with a high-pressure mercury lamp (365 nm) for over 12 h to get yellow crystals of 1a. Anal. Calcd for C22H16CdN2O4: C, 54.51; H, 3.33; N, 5.78; found: C, 54.85; H, 3.38; N, 5.72%. IR (KBr disc): 3451 (m), 1633 (s), 1605 (s), 1581 (s), 1551 (s), 1428 (w), 1395 (s), 1322 (s), 1222 (w), 1135 (w), 1098 (w), 989 (m), 838 (m), 790 (m), 767 (m), 727 (m), 691 (m), 539 (m) cm–1.

Synthesis of [{Cd<sub>2</sub>(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,4-BDC)<sub>2</sub>}­·2MeCN]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3a</bold>)

Yellow crystals of 3a were obtained from 3 (0.2 g) in a manner similar to that used in the isolation of 1a. Anal. Calcd for C22H16CdN2O4: C, 54.51; H, 3.33; N, 5.78; found: C, 54.73; H, 3.55; N, 6.05%. IR (KBr disc): 3470 (m), 1604 (s), 1566 (s), 1504 (m), 1400 (s), 1384 (s), 1223 (m), 1099 (m), 1013 (m), 994 (m), 882 (w), 826 (m), 793 (w), 744 (s), 619 (m), 512 (m) cm–1.

Synthesis of [{Cd<sub>2</sub>(4-tp-3-lad)­(1,3,5-HBTC)<sub>2</sub>}·(ppene)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4a</bold>)

Yellow crystals of 4a were produced from 4 (0.2 g) using an analogous approach to that in the preparation of 1a. Anal. Calcd for C30H22CdN3O6: C, 56.93; H, 3.50; N, 6.64; found: C, 57.25; H, 3.57; N, 6.52%. IR (KBr disc): 3451 (s), 1616 (s), 1604 (s), 1564 (s), 1505 (m), 1427 (s), 1383 (s), 1222 (m), 1098 (w), 1010 (m), 995 (m), 841 (w), 795 (w), 755 (m), 724 (s), 694 (m), 642 (m), 513 (m) cm–1.

Isolation of 4-tp-3-lad

A mixture of 1a or 3a (100 mg), NaOH (0.1 g, 0.25 mmol), ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) disodium salt (0.1 g), H2O (40 mL), and CH2Cl2 (40 mL) was placed in a 150 mL flask and stirred overnight. The organic layer was separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic layers were dried with anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvents were removed under reduced pressure to yield off-white powders of 4-tp-3-lad. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6): 3.5 (2H, s, cyclobutane), 4.3 (2H, s, cyclobutane), 7.0 (4H, d, py), 8.3 (4H, d, py).

cln_elements.content: In order to explore the fluorescent sensing properties of these compounds, we investigated the photoluminescent properties of 1–5, 1a, 3a, and 4a, and ppene in water ( and 4S). Upon excitation at 360 nm, the ppene ligand dispersed in water exhibited two emission bands centered at λmax = 390 and 410 nm, respectively. The observed emission origins of ppene probably contributed to the intraligand π–π* and n−π* transitions. When excited at 330 nm (1) or 360 nm (2), compounds 1 and 2 displayed similar absorption mission bands with emission maxima at 394 and 425 nm (1), 405 and 425 nm (2), respectively. Upon excitation at 360 nm (3 and 4), or 370 nm (5), compounds 3–5 presented strong photoluminescence with emission maxima at 404 nm (3), 420 nm (4), and 410 nm (5), respectively. These emission bands of 1–5 can be largely assigned to a ligand-centered emission. Compared with that of ppene, the emission maxima of 1–5 was red-shifted, which may be due to the coordination between ppene and Cd­(II). Besides, the emission peak of 1a (λmax = 394 nm) was similar to that of 1 (Figure S4). However, a red-shift of the emission maxima from 3 to 3a (λmax = 432 nm) and a blue shift of the emission maxima from 4 to 4a (λmax = 413 nm) were observed.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

In order to explore the fluorescent sensing properties of these compounds, we investigated the photoluminescent properties of 1-5, 1a, 3a, and 4a, and ppene in water ( and 4S). Upon excitation at 360 nm, the ppene ligand dispersed in water exhibited two emission bands centered at λmax = 390 and 410 nm, respectively. The observed emission origins of ppene probably contributed to the intraligand π-π* and n-π* transitions. When excited at 330 nm (1) or 360 nm (2), compounds 1 and 2 displayed similar absorption mission bands with emission maxima at 394 and 425 nm (1), 405 and 425 nm (2), respectively. Upon excitation at 360 nm (3 and 4), or 370 nm (5), compounds 3-5 presented strong photoluminescence with emission maxima at 404 nm (3), 420 nm (4), and 410 nm (5), respectively. These emission bands of 1-5 can be largely assigned to a ligand-centered emission. Compared with that of ppene, the emission maxima of 1-5 was red-shifted, which may be due to the coordination between ppene and Cd(II). Besides, the emission peak of 1a (λmax = 394 nm) was similar to that of 1 (Figure S4). However, a red-shift of the emission maxima from 3 to 3a (λmax = 432 nm) and a blue shift of the emission maxima from 4 to 4a (λmax = 413 nm) were observed.
